required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Change In Diaphragmatic Thickness Predicts Extubation Success
clinical_study.official_title: Can the Diaphragm Predict the Course of Mechanical Ventilation? A Prospective Study Evaluating Several M-Mode Ultrasound Measured Diaphragmatic Parameters and Their Effects on Weaning From Mechanical Ventilation

brief_summary.textblock: We will investigate whether measurement of the change in thickness of the diaphragm during the respiratory cycle by ultrasound can predict extubation success in a 48 hour window. We will also asses whether this is only possible on low levels of pressure support as has been shown previously, or if this technique retains its predictive power at higher levels of pressure support.

primary_outcome.description: Discontinuation from mechanical ventilation in 48 hours from ultrasound PI has left the institution. Efforts made to contact the PI were unsuccessful. No study data available.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 48 hours from removal of ventilatory support
secondary_outcome.description: Reinstitution of mechanical ventilation within 48 hours of extubation PI has left the institution. Efforts made to contact the PI were unsuccessful. No study data available.

arm_group.description: all patients enrolled will have an ultrasound of their diaphragm performed once they are on a pressure support trial. Intervention: Diaphragm Ultrasound

intervention.description: Once on a pressure support weaning trial, enrolled subjects will have an ultrasound of their right hemidiaphragm performed on three levels of pressure support: 15/5 10/5 and 5/5

study_pop.textblock: Patients on mechanical ventilation in the intensive care unit

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- age greater than 18, ventilated for >24 hours
Exclusion Criteria:
- already chronically on mechanical ventilatory support, already has tracheostomy, has pathology that obscures visualization of the right hemidiaphragm, has acute stroke either hemorrhagic or ischemic, cannot identify appropriate decision maker to get informed consent.
